Dear Ms. Berkobien:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Health services; policies and procedures.
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4142
Section (1) An institution shall establish and follow written health service
Description policies and procedures addressing all of the following:
(a) Routine and emergency medical, and dental, and
behavioral health care.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth A was placed at the facility in February 2024 and mental
health services did not allegedly begin until August 2024.
Investigation The Complainant was interviewed on 09/04/2024 and had no
additional information to provide.
Youth A was interviewed with DHHS Worker 1 over the phone on
09/04/2024. Youth A confirmed he has a current therapist but
could not recall her name. He stated he often refuses to speak
with her. He could not recall the last time he had an individual
appointment with her. Youth A stated that he participates in
regular group therapy.
Youth A’s DHHS Foster Care Worker was interviewed over the
phone on 09/04/2024 with DHHS Worker 1. She stated she had
received intermittent information regarding the mental health
services of Youth A during his time placed at the facility. She
believed Youth A had not had the consistent once per week
individual therapy since his placement but could not confirm that
information. DHHS Foster Care Worker referred to Staff 1 as a
point person at the facility that has communicated well with her
during Youth A’s placement and had told her about the therapist
switches over the course of his six month placement.
The facility Chief Administrator was interviewed on 09/06/2024
with DHHS Worker 1 during an unannounced, face-to-face visit at
the facility. She confirmed Youth A had an assigned therapist at
that time, but this assignment had changed since his placement at
the facility and hiring issues had been a cause in the changes.
2

Staff 1 was interviewed on 09/06/2024 with DHHS Worker 1
during an unannounced, face-to-face visit at the facility. She
stated that her role in the facility was as a Family Transition
Coordinator and did not act as a staff within ratio, but often
communicated with youth’s families and caseworkers during
placement and after discharge. Staff 1 recalled speaking with
Youth A’s DHHS Foster Care Worker regarding his services but
could not comment on specifics of his therapy.
Documents reviewed:
• Therapy records for Youth A were provided. Since his
placement in February 2024 Youth A had 14 individual
therapy appointments during the 28 weeks of placement at
the time of review.
• Facility Program Statement for the Jacob Hall program was
provided and reviewed. This documentation describes the
programming offered to youth including individual therapy
being offered at least once per week, and more often as
needed.
Analysis The agency is found in non-compliance as per interviews of youth
and staff and documentation reviewed. Youth A was not offered
individual therapy as per what is described in the facility program
statement.
Conclusion VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Rule Code Incident reporting
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4150
Section (3) If an institution determines that a youth is absent without legal
Description permission, then the institution shall immediately report the
information to law enforcement, the parent/legal guardian or
next of kin, the licensing authority, and the referring agency.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth A AWOL'ed on 08/26/2024 and the facility notified a family
member and not the referring agency.
Investigation The Complainant was interviewed on 09/04/2024 and had no
additional information to provide.
3

Youth A’s DHHS Foster Care Worker was interviewed over the
phone on 09/04/2024 with DHHS Worker 1. She stated that Youth
A had AWOL’ed on 08/26/2024 at about 11:00pm. She stated she
received notice of this AWOL the following day, and her main
concern was a family member of Youth A had received notice of
this AWOL from the facility prior to herself. DHHS Foster Care
Worker stated she had previously provided the contact information
for this family member as a support to Youth A, but she did not
believe that this person should receive incident notifications such
as AWOLs. In addition, DHHS Foster Care Worker expressed
concern that the facility had not been able to provide clear
information on Youth A being back at the facility or still AWOL on
the day following. DHHS Foster Care Worker also reported Youth
A had another recent AWOL on 08/31/2024 at approximately
10:00 pm. She stated she received an email from the facility
notifying her of this on 09/01/2024. A request was made of this
caseworker to provide any email documentation of what was
described and as of the writing of this report this had not been
provided.
Staff 1 was interviewed on 09/06/2024 with DHHS Worker 1
during an unannounced, face-to-face visit at the facility. She
stated she had been in communication with Youth A’s DHHS
Foster Care Worker during much of Youth A’s recent activity at the
facility, including confirming his return from AWOL that began on
09/01/2024 and ended with his return on 09/02/2024.
Documents reviewed:
• Facility incident report documentation for Youth A was
provided and reviewed. Dates and communications
described in this documentation were consistent with
interviews provided.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as per interviews with staff and
other individuals and documentation reviewed. There was no
evidence found that the facility had not met the rule requirements
for AWOL incident notifications.
Conclusion VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
Rule Code Sufficiency of staff.
Title
4

Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4126
Section (1) The licensee shall have a sufficient number of administrative,
Description supervisory, social service, direct care, and other staff on duty
to perform the prescribed functions required by these
administrative rules and in the agency's program statement
and to provide for the continual needs, protection, and
supervision of residents
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Male and female residents are being found in bed with each other.
Investigation The Complainant was interviewed on 09/04/2024 and had no
additional information to provide.
Youth A was interviewed with DHHS Worker 1 over the phone on
09/04/2024. He stated there are separate girls units from the boys
units in the facility, and that he has never seen or heard of youth
sneaking from one unit to another during sleeping hours. In
addition, he stated there is a rule during school hours and
recreation time that boys and girls are not supposed to talk to
each other. Youth A admitted to taking part in recent AWOLs with
a group of other youth, and he has heard that youth were
participating in sexual activity while on AWOL, offsite and out of
line of sight from staff. He repeated he did not think this was
occurring while in the building.
Youth B was interviewed with DHHS Worker 1 over the phone on
09/04/2024. He stated he has heard of youth attempting to talk
while in school and try to make plans for what they could do while
AWOL, and also heard youth try to do the same while participating
in outside time and recreation. Part of this planning was for youth
who wanted to attempt sexual activity while AWOL. Youth B
confirmed he has never heard of these things occurring while in
the building or on site otherwise.
Youth A’s DHHS Foster Care Worker was interviewed over the
phone on 09/04/2024 with DHHS Worker 1. She stated she had
heard of instances from Youth A where youth allegedly came in
and out of the building through other youth’s windows and also
had slept together, but did not have any specific names, dates or
other information to provide.
Youth C was interviewed on 09/06/2024 with DHHS Worker 1
during an unannounced, face-to-face visit at the facility. Youth C
5

confirmed his participation in recent AWOLs from the facility with
other youth at the same time. He stated he knew there were
instances where youth slept together while offsite and out of line
of sight of staff, but never heard of this occurring when youth were
in the building. Youth C believed this would not be possible during
sleeping hours in the building because staff were always present.
Youth D was interviewed on 09/06/2024 with DHHS Worker 1
during an unannounced, face-to-face visit at the facility. Youth D
did not believe there were any youth sneaking into bedrooms of
other youth while in the building.
The facility Chief Administrator was interviewed on 09/06/2024
with DHHS Worker 1 during an unannounced, face-to-face visit at
the facility. She believed there were no instances of youth
sneaking into the bedrooms of other youth in the facility because
there was a recent instance of similar behavior from youth that
occurred while they were AWOL. The Chief Administrator recalled
Youth A had told her that he took a blanket with him while going
AWOL and used it to sleep with two other youth while at a local
park. She described current struggles within the facility where
youth were commonly AWOL’ing and leaving the facility
altogether, as well as leaving the building and remaining outside
and refusing direction of staff while still under line of sight
supervision. The Chief Administrator stated she had not
encountered any situation that raised concern that youth could be
sleeping together or sneaking into each other’s bedrooms while
under staff supervision.
Staff 2 was interviewed on 09/06/2024 with DHHS Worker 1
during an unannounced, face-to-face visit at the facility. He
stated that his position as a Crisis Response Worker afforded him
recent opportunities to interact with youth that were coming and
going from AWOLs from the facility in efforts to de-escalate them.
He stated he had not had any concern that youth had snuck into
bedrooms of other youth while in the building and had also been
told that youth had slept together while on AWOL. Staff 2 recalled
a specific instance when Youth A had come back inside the
building and had stated he was going to stay in the facility, only to
grab a blanket and AWOL again.
Youth E was interviewed over the phone on 09/23/2024. He
stated he AWOL’ed from the facility several times before his
placement ended in early September and recalled similar
instances to what had been described by others, youth sleeping
6

next to each other while AWOL. Youth E believed this had not
happened while in the facility and under staff supervision.
Documents reviewed:
• Facility policy titled Proximity and Awareness Staffing
Protocol, last dated 10/23/2023, was provided and
reviewed. This policy and procedure outlined staff
requirements for line of sight both within the building and
when youth were going AWOL. No concerns over
requirements for staff and their supervision of youth were
noted.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as per interviews with youth
and staff. There was no evidence found that youth were sneaking
into each other’s beds while under staff supervision.
Conclusion VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
Rule Code Facility and premises maintenance
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4407
Section (1) A facility and premises shall be maintained in a clean,
Description comfortable, and safe condition. The facility shall be located on
land that is properly drained.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation The facility has numerous broken doors and windows that the
residents sneak in and out of.
Investigation The Complainant was interviewed on 09/04/2024 and had no
additional information to provide.
DHHS Worker 1 toured the facility on 09/04/2024 and provided
pictures of various boarded up windows that had been broken. No
safety issues were noted.
Youth A’s DHHS Foster Care Worker was interviewed over the
phone on 09/04/2024 with DHHS Worker 1. She stated she had
been at the facility recently to visit her assigned youth and had
seen many windows that had been broken in various forms but did
not see any that posed any safety issues like openings or broken
7

glass. She reported that they were commonly boarded up with
plywood.
Licensing Consultant 2 stated that she was onsite at the facility
on 09/05/2024 and witnessed broken windows, but none that were
not properly addressed or caused any safety issues.
Youth C and Youth D were interviewed separately on 09/06/2024
with DHHS Worker 1 during an unannounced, face-to-face visit at
the facility. They both stated that broken windows were more and
more common within the facility, but they had not seen any that
were broken and did not have swift and proper attention to clean
them up and board them up to reduce any safety issues.
The facility Chief Administrator was interviewed on 09/06/2024
with DHHS Worker 1 during an unannounced, face-to-face visit at
the facility. She confirmed there had been a recent increase in
broken windows but discussed facility procedure on cleaning any
unsafe debris such as glass and having them boarded up in a
timely manner. She did not believe there had been any issues
accomplishing this procedure despite the increase in property
destruction by youth.
Supervisor 1 provided this writer and DHHS Worker 1 with a tour
of the facility on 09/06/2024. Many broken windows were noted
but none that had not been properly addressed. Supervisor 1 did
show a window at the end of a hallway in one of the units (not in a
bedroom) that had its locking mechanism broken, which would
allow for youth to enter and exit. It was confirmed that the facility
is not secure, and exit doors are not locked and would allow youth
to AWOL if they attempt to do so.
Youth E’s Probation Worker was interviewed over the phone on
09/17/2024. She stated that she had visited the facility several
times leading up to Youth E’s discharge. She confirmed seeing
broken windows but never any that had not received proper
attention to clean them up.
Youth E was interviewed over the phone on 09/23/2024. He
recalled other youth attempting to break windows prior to his
discharge, both breaking the glass and the locking mechanism on
windowsills. He stated he never witnessed any occurrence of this
without staff reacting quickly to clean and board them up.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as per interviews with youth,
staff and other individuals. There was no evidence found that
8

there were broken windows within the facility that had not been
addressed properly.
Conclusion VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
